title: Standish Wood Walking Route

images.title: Ethan Doyle White [CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: One of the two Bronze Age round barrows on Standish Wood near Randwick in Gloucestershire. This is the smaller and more westerly of the two barrows, which are only a few metres apart.

images.title: Ethan Doyle White [CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The bank of the Iron Age cross dyke

images.title: Philip Halling / Standish Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hoar frost on beech trees

images.title: Ethan Doyle White [CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Part of the Iron Age cross dyke in Standish Wood near Randwick in Gloucestershire. The bank is shielded in shadow while the dyke is lit by the sun.

images.title: Ethan Doyle White [CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: North-facing viewpoint from the northern end of the Iron Age cross dyke in Standish Wood near Randwick in Gloucestershire.

images.title: Ethan Doyle White [CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: One of the Standish Wood Round Barrows. This is the more easterly of the two barrows, which are only a few metres apart.

description: Enjoy peaceful woodland trails in this large area of woodland near Whiteshill, Stroud. In the springtime there are carpets of bluebells to enjoy. The walk can be extended by climbing Haresfield Beacon for wonderful views over the Severn Vale and the Cotswolds.
